item.title: Luce, thank you for that kind introduction.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I want to talk to you tonight not about politics and not about party.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And while there are many important issues we'll hear discussed in this convention and
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: throughout this campaign, tonight I want to talk to you from my heart about our hearts.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I want to talk not about what divides us, but what holds us together as an American family. I
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: want to talk to you tonight about that one great thing that unites us, that one thing that brings us
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: our greatest joy when times are good, and the deepest solace in our dark hours.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Tonight I want to talk to you about love.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I want to talk to you about the deep and abiding love I have for a man I met at a dance many
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: years ago. And the profound love I have, and I know we share, for this country.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I want to talk to you about that love so deep only a mother can fathom it -- the love we have for
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: our children and our children's children.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And I want us to think tonight about the love we all share for those Americans, our brothers and
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: sisters, who are going through difficult times, whose days are never easy, nights are always long,
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: and whose work never seems done.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: They are here among us tonight in this hall; they are here in neighborhoods across Tampa and all
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: across America. The parents who lie awake at night side by side, wondering how they'll be able
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: to pay the mortgage or make the rent; the single dad who's working extra hours tonight, so that
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: his kids can buy some new clothes to go back to school, can take a school trip or play a sport, so
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: his kids can feel... like the other kids.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And the working moms who love their jobs but would like to work just a little less to spend more
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: time with the kids, but that's just out of the question with this economy. Or that couple who
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: would like to have another child, but wonder how will they afford it.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I've been all across this country for the past year and a half and heard these stories of how hard it
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: is to get ahead now. I've heard your voices: "I'm running in place," "we just can't get ahead."
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Sometimes I think that late at night, if we were all silent for just a few moments and listened
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: carefully, we could hear a great collective sigh from the moms and dads across America who
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: made it through another day, and know that they'll make it through another one tomorrow. But in
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: that end of the day moment, they just aren't sure how.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And if you listen carefully, you'll hear the women sighing a little bit more than the men. It's how
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: it is, isn't it?
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: It's the moms who always have to work a little harder, to make everything right.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: It's the moms of this nation -- single, married, widowed -- who really hold this country together.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: We're the mothers, we're the wives, we're the grandmothers, we're the big sisters, we're the little
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: sisters, we're the daughters.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You know it's true, don't you?
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You're the ones who always have to do a little more.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You know what it's like to work a little harder during the day to earn the respect you deserve at
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: work and then come home to help with that book report which just has to be done.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You know what those late night phone calls with an elderly parent are like and the long weekend
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: drives just to see how they're doing.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You know the fastest route to the local emergency room and which doctors actually answer the
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: phone when you call at night.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You know what it's like to sit in that graduation ceremony and wonder how it was that so many
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: long days turned into years that went by so quickly.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You are the best of America.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You are the hope of America.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: There would not be an America without you.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Tonight, we salute you and sing your praises.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I'm not sure if men really understand this, but I don't think there's a woman in America who
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: really expects her life to be easy. In our own ways, we all know better!
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And that's fine. We don't want easy. But these last few years have been harder than they needed
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: to be. It's all the little things -- that price at the pump you just can't believe, the grocery bills that
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: just get bigger; all those things that used to be free, like school sports, are now one more bill to
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: pay. It's all the little things that pile up to become big things. And the big things -- the good
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: jobs, the chance at college, that home you want to buy, just get harder. Everything has become
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: harder.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: We're too smart to know there aren't easy answers. But we're not dumb enough to accept that
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: there aren't better answers.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And that is where this boy I met at a high school dance comes in.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: His name is Mitt Romney and you really should get to know him.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I could tell you why I fell in love with him -- he was tall, laughed a lot, was nervous -- girls like
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: that, it shows the guy's a little intimidated -- and he was nice to my parents but he was really glad
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: when my parents weren't around.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: That's a good thing. And he made me laugh.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I am the granddaughter of a Welsh coal miner who was determined that his kids get out of the
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: mines. My dad got his first job when he was six years old, in a little village in Wales called
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Nantyffyllon, cleaning bottles at the Colliers Arms.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: When he was 15, dad came to America. In our country, he saw hope and an opportunity to
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: escape from poverty. He moved to a small town in the great state of Michigan. There, he started
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: a business -- one he built himself, by the way.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He raised a family. And he became mayor of our town.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: My dad would often remind my brothers and me how fortunate we were to grow up in a place
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: like America. He wanted us to have every opportunity that came with life in this country -- and
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: so he pushed us to be our best and give our all.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Inside the houses that lined the streets of our town, there were a lot of good fathers teaching their
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: sons and daughters those same values. I didn't know it at the time, but one of those dads was my
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: future father-in-law, George Romney.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Mitt's dad never graduated from college. Instead, he became a carpenter.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He worked hard, and he became the head of a car company, and then the governor of Michigan.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: When Mitt and I met and fell in love, we were determined not to let anything stand in the way of
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: our life together. I was an Episcopalian. He was a Mormon.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: We were very young. Both still in college. There were many reasons to delay marriage, and you
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: know? We just didn't care. We got married and moved into a basement apartment. We walked
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: to class together, shared the housekeeping, and ate a lot of pasta and tuna fish. Our desk was a
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: door propped up on sawhorses. Our dining room table was a fold down ironing board in the
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: kitchen. Those were very special days.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Then our first son came along. All at once I'm 22 years old, with a baby and a husband who's
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: going to business school and law school at the same time, and I can tell you, probably like every
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: other girl who finds herself in a new life far from family and friends, with a new baby and a new
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: husband, that it dawned on me that I had absolutely no idea what I was getting into.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: That was 42 years ago. Now we have five sons and 18 grandchildren and I'm still in love with
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: that boy I met at a high school dance.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I read somewhere that Mitt and I have a "storybook marriage." Well, in the storybooks I read,
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: there were never long, long, rainy winter afternoons in a house with five boys screaming at once.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And those storybooks never seemed to have chapters called MS or Breast Cancer.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: A storybook marriage? No, not at all. What Mitt Romney and I have is a real marriage.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I know this good and decent man for what he is -- warm and loving and patient.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He has tried to live his life with a set of values centered on family, faith, and love of one's fellow
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: man. From the time we were first married, I've seen him spend countless hours helping others.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I've seen him drop everything to help a friend in trouble, and been there when late-night calls of
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: panic came from a member of our church whose child had been taken to the hospital.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You may not agree with Mitt's positions on issues or his politics. Massachusetts is only 13%
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Republican, so it's not like that's a shock.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: But let me say this to every American who is thinking about who should be our next President:
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: No one will work harder.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: No one will care more.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: No one will move heaven and earth like Mitt Romney to make this country a better place to live!
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: It's true that Mitt has been successful at each new challenge he has taken on. It amazes me to see
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: his history of success actually being attacked. Are those really the values that made our country
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: great? As a mom of five boys, do we want to raise our children to be afraid of success?
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Do we send our children out in the world with the advice, "Try to do... okay?"
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: And let's be honest. If the last four years had been more successful, do we really think there
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: would be this attack on Mitt Romney's success?
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Of course not.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Mitt will be the first to tell you that he is the most fortunate man in the world. He had two loving
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: parents who gave him strong values and taught him the value of work. He had the chance to get
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: the education his father never had.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: But as his partner on this amazing journey, I can tell you Mitt Romney was not handed success.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He built it.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He stayed in Massachusetts after graduate school and got a job. I saw the long hours that started
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: with that first job. I was there when he and a small group of friends talked about starting a new
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: company. I was there when they struggled and wondered if the whole idea just wasn't going to
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: work. Mitt's reaction was to work harder and press on.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Today that company has become another great American success story.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Has it made those who started the company successful beyond their dreams?
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Yes, it has.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: It allowed us to give our sons the chance at good educations and made all those long hours of
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: book reports and homework worth every minute. It's given us the deep satisfaction of being able
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: to help others in ways that we could never have imagined. Mitt doesn't like to talk about how he
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: has helped others because he sees it as a privilege, not a political talking point. And we're no
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: different than the millions of Americans who quietly help their neighbors, their churches and
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: their communities. They don't do it so that others will think more of them.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: They do it because there IS no greater joy.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: "Give and it shall be given unto you."
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: But because this is America, that small company which grew has helped so many others lead
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: better lives. The jobs that grew from the risks they took have become college educations, first
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: homes. That success has helped fund scholarships, pensions, and retirement funds. This is the
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: genius of America: dreams fulfilled help others launch new dreams.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: At every turn in his life, this man I met at a high school dance, has helped lift up others. He did
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: it with the Olympics, when many wanted to give up.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He did it in Massachusetts, where he guided a state from economic crisis to unemployment of
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: just 4.7%.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Under Mitt, Massachusetts's schools were the best in the nation. The best. He started the John
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: and Abigail Adams scholarships, which give the top 25% of high school graduates a four-year
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: tuition-free scholarship.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This is the man America needs.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This is the man who will wake up every day with the determination to solve the problems that
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: others say can't be solved, to fix what others say is beyond repair. This is the man who will work
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: harder than anyone so that we can work a little less hard.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I can't tell you what will happen over the next four years. But I can only stand here tonight, as a
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: wife, a mother, a grandmother, an American, and make you this solemn commitment:
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This man will not fail.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This man will not let us down.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This man will lift up America!
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: It has been 47 years since that tall, kind of charming young man brought me home from our first
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: dance. Not every day since has been easy.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: But he still makes me laugh. And never once did I have a single reason to doubt that I was the
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: luckiest woman in the world.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: I said tonight I wanted to talk to you about love. Look into your hearts.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This is our country.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: This is our future.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: These are our children and grandchildren.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: You can trust Mitt.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He loves America.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: He will take us to a better place, just as he took me home safely from that dance.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Give him that chance.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Give America that chance.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: God bless each of you and God Bless the United States of America.
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Paid for by the Committee on Arrangements for the 2012 Republican National Convention
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: www.GOPConvention2012.com - Phone: (813) 381-5588
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney

item.title: Not Authorized By Any Candidate or Candidate's Committee
item.author: Mrs. Ann Romney
